title: How to Buy a Dehumidifier

steps.headline: Look for signs that your home is too humid.
steps.description: They can include condensation on windows, allergies, musty smells, and wall stains.

steps.headline: Consult a home inspector to find out if damp conditions are causing mold.
steps.description: Mold can affect property values and a home inspector can tell you how to mitigate mold problems.

steps.headline: Buy a hygrometer.
steps.description: This small temperature and humidity gauge are available online for $15 to $30. Measure the humidity in each room of your home to see how many rooms require a humidifier. Hygrometers are available in digital and mechanical displays. Digital hygrometers with LCD displays are slightly more expensive and may not pick up low levels of humidity. Make sure you reset the hygrometer as you move from room to room and wait an appropriate amount of time before judging the humidity.

steps.headline: Measure the space you want to dehumidify.
steps.description: You will need to convert the measurement to square feet or square m. For rectangles or squares, you can simply multiply the length measurement in feet by the width measurement in feet. You can also use an online calculator at http://www.squarefootage.org/square-footage-calculator.php

steps.headline: Look for tabletop models if you want to dehumidify a small single room.
steps.description: A 500 square foot (47 square m) room will need a dehumidifier that can process between 10 and 16 pints (4.7 to 7.6 l) of water in a 24-hour period.

steps.headline: Choose a model that can process 14 to 23 pints (6.6 to 10.9 l) of water per hour for a space of 1,000 square feet (93 square m).
steps.description: A floor model can work for 1 large room or a few smaller rooms that are connected by a door or entryway.

steps.headline: Upgrade to a dehumidifier that can process 18 to 30 pints (8.5 to 14.2 l) for a space that is 1,500 square feet (139 square m).
steps.description: These models can be as large as a window air conditioner. If you plan to use a dehumidifier in several rooms, pick a model that is on casters, so you can push it from room to room.

steps.headline: Opt to buy a whole house humidifier if you have a space of 2,000 or more square feet (186 square m).
steps.description: You can attach it to existing air circulation systems for best results. It will need to process between 22 and 44 pints (10.4 to 20.8 l) of water per day.

steps.headline: Judge your needs based on how wet the areas are.
steps.description: Laundry rooms and basements usually need the maximum dehumidifying power for the space.

steps.headline: Go to a store to view several dehumidifier models.
steps.description: If you have a home improvement store or a large department store, you may be able to compare accessibility factors before you purchase a model. If you can’t find dehumidifiers to test, then make sure you have a quality assurance and/or satisfaction guarantee.

steps.headline: Assess how easily you can empty the water bucket.
steps.description: If you are using a small to a medium-sized dehumidifier, you will probably need to empty the bucket manually. The bucket should be accessible through the front and the top.

steps.headline: Choose a dehumidifier that empties through a hose, if you are using a larger model.
steps.description: Basement and whole house humidifiers may require a hose to empty large amounts of water that is removed from the air. Ensure you have a place in your house, such as a utility sink or a drainpipe that will work for this purpose. Whole-house dehumidifiers require a hose that extends outside of the house. You should employ an installer to make sure the hose is emptying into an appropriate place on your property.

steps.headline: Look for Energy Star appliances.
steps.description: These models are certified as energy efficient by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) and the US Department of Energy. Check with your power company to see if you can receive a credit on your bill for using an Energy Star device.

steps.headline: Measure the temperature in your rooms.
steps.description: If the temperature regularly drops below 65 degrees Fahrenheit (18 degrees Celsius), you will need to buy a special cold-weather and frost-resistant model. These models will work to approximately 42 degrees Fahrenheit (5.5 degrees Celsius).

steps.headline: Pick a model with a built-in humidistat.
steps.description: You can control the machine based on the humidity level in the room. It should also have several safety features, such as an automatic shut off if the water bucket is full.

steps.headline: Sign up for a warranty that lasts at least one year.
steps.description: You may choose to upgrade for an additional 5 years of protection, but try to avoid expensive service agreements.
